sections.title: Critical safety alert
sections.content: Professional crisis intervention protocols for mental health emergencies, suicidal ideation, and psychiatric crises require immediate assessment and intervention. All mental health emergencies require immediate safety assessment. If risk indicators are present, take steps to ensure patient safety, remove access to means, and consider emergency intervention.

steps.title: Immediate Safety Assessment
steps.subtitle: Ensure scene safety. Remove potential weapons/means. Ask directly: “Are you thinking about killing yourself right now?”

steps.title: Establish Rapport & Support
steps.subtitle: Use empathetic approach: “I’m here to help you stay safe.” Validate feelings without judgment.

steps.title: Risk Assessment
steps.subtitle: Assess intent, plan specificity, means access, timeline. Use SAMHSA suicide risk assessment protocol.

steps.title: Crisis Intervention
steps.subtitle: Explore ambivalence, identify protective factors, discuss reasons for living, validate emotional pain.

steps.title: Safety Planning
steps.subtitle: Assess airway, breathing, circulation. Treat overdose, bleeding, or other medical threats.

steps.title: Disposition Planning
steps.subtitle: Determine appropriate level of care: emergency hold, psychiatric evaluation, or outpatient follow-up.

steps.title: Resource Connection
steps.subtitle: Assess airway, breathing, circulation. Treat overdose, bleeding, or other medical threats.

steps.title: Medical Stabilization
steps.subtitle: Assess airway, breathing, circulation. Treat overdose, bleeding, or other medical threats.

steps.title: Continuous Monitoring
steps.subtitle: Establish 1:1 observation. Remove all harmful objects. Place in safe, monitored environment.

steps.title: Emergency Medical Care
steps.subtitle: IV access, vital signs, O2 monitoring. Consider antidotes (Narcan, activated charcoal). Protect C-spine if indicated.

steps.title: Psychiatric Assessment
steps.subtitle: Complete mental status exam when medically stable. Assess ongoing suicide risk using standardized tools.

steps.title: Safety Measures
steps.subtitle: Consider involuntary psychiatric hold. Family notification per safety protocol. Document all interventions.

steps.title: Immediate Threat Assessment
steps.subtitle: Assess immediate danger to others. Identify specific threatened individuals. Document exact threats.

steps.title: Scene Safety
steps.subtitle: Ensure scene safety. Consider law enforcement involvement. Evaluate access to weapons or means of harm.

steps.title: Duty to Warn Protocol
steps.subtitle: Tarasoff duty: Warn identifiable potential victims. Contact law enforcement if imminent danger exists.

steps.title: Emergency Services
steps.subtitle: Notify psychiatric emergency services immediately. Consider emergency psychiatric hold (72-hour hold).

steps.title: De-escalation
steps.subtitle: Use calm, non-threatening approach. Avoid challenging delusions directly. Maintain safe distance.

steps.title: Documentation & Transport
steps.subtitle: Document all notifications made. Coordinate with law enforcement for safe transport if needed.

steps.title: Acknowledge the thoughts and reach out right away
steps.subtitle: Recognize the thoughts without judgment or shame—they are a symptom of pain, not a personal failing or permanent state. Talk to someone immediately to reduce isolation.

steps.title: Seek professional evaluation and treatment
steps.subtitle: Passive ideation often links to underlying issues like depression, anxiety, trauma, or sleep problems. A mental health professional can assess risk and create a tailored plan.

steps.title: Create a personalized safety plan
steps.subtitle: A safety plan gives concrete steps for when thoughts intensify, helping you stay safe and regain control.

steps.title: Prioritize foundational self-care
steps.subtitle:
Basic physical needs directly impact mood and thought patterns. When depleted, passive thoughts often worsen.

Focus on small, consistent habits:
• Aim for regular sleep (even if imperfect)
• Eat nourishing meals
• Gentle movement (a short walk)
• Basic hygiene and routines

steps.title: Practice grounding and thought-challenging techniques
steps.subtitle:
These tools help interrupt and reduce the power of passive thoughts in the moment.

• Grounding: Name 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, etc.
• Mindfulness/meditation: Observe thoughts as passing clouds without engaging.
• Reality-check negatives: Ask "Is this thought a fact or a feeling?" or "What would I tell a friend in this situation?"
• Engage in absorbing activities: (music, reading, hobbies) for distraction and small moments of relief.

steps.title: Build long-term support and resilience
steps.subtitle:
Address isolation and cultivate reasons for living through ongoing connection and purpose.

• Stay connected to supportive people or groups (in-person or online communities)
• Follow through with therapy appointments and track progress
• Explore values-based goals (even tiny ones like "learn one new skill")
• Limit substances that worsen mood
• Reassess regularly—many people see thoughts fade as circumstances and coping improve.

These steps work best when combined with professional guidance. If thoughts intensify, include plans to act, or you feel unsafe, contact 988 or Contact Emergency Medical Services immediately. Pain can feel endless, but it is often temporary, and effective help exists—recovery is common and realistic.

steps.title: Safety & De-escalation
steps.subtitle: Ensure scene safety. Use calm, non-confrontational approach. Assess for agitation, psychosis, or disorientation.

steps.title: Mental Status Assessment
steps.subtitle: Assess orientation, thought process, perceptions. Look for hallucinations, delusions, or command voices.

steps.title: Risk Assessment
steps.subtitle: Evaluate risk to self and others. Assess need for involuntary treatment. Consider substance use influence.

steps.title: Crisis Intervention
steps.subtitle: Provide reality orientation. Use therapeutic communication. Avoid arguing with delusions.

steps.title: Medical Evaluation
steps.subtitle: Rule out medical causes: infection, metabolic issues, substance intoxication/withdrawal, head injury.

steps.title: Treatment Planning
steps.subtitle: Consider medication for severe agitation. Plan for psychiatric evaluation and appropriate disposition.

steps.title: Call Emergency Medical Services for Stabilization and Safety
steps.subtitle: The first priority is treating any physical injuries or medical complications from the attempt - Stabilization, Monitoring Vital Signs, and ensuring physical safety.

steps.title: Comprehensive Psychiatric Evaluation and Risk Assessment
steps.subtitle: Once medically stable, a full mental health assessment evaluates the reasons for the attempt, current suicidal thoughts, underlying conditions (e.g., depression, trauma, substance use), and future risk level.

steps.title: Acute Treatment and Level of Care
steps.subtitle: Based on the assessment, short-term intensive care may be recommended, such as inpatient psychiatric hospitalization for safety and stabilization, or intensive outpatient programs. Treatments can include medication for mood disorders, crisis counseling, and initial therapy.

steps.title: Personalized Safety Plan
steps.subtitle: A safety plan is a written, step-by-step tool to recognize warning signs and respond effectively during distress. It includes coping strategies, support contacts, and ways to limit access to lethal means (e.g., securing medications, firearms).

steps.title: Follow-Up and Care
steps.subtitle:
The highest-risk period is right after leaving the Hospital or Emergency Room.
Call for follow-up within 24–72 hours via phone, text, or in-person appointment to check in, reinforce the plan, and connect to ongoing services.

steps.title: Long-Term Recovery, Therapy, and Support
steps.subtitle:
Ongoing care addresses underlying issues, builds coping skills, and fosters hope and connection. This includes therapy (e.g., medication management, support groups for attempt survivors, and lifestyle changes like sleep, exercise, and social connections).
Connect with a therapist or psychiatrist experienced in suicide prevention. Practice self-compassion—be kind to yourself during recovery, involve family/friends and monitor progress with regular check-ins.

This is not a substitute for personalized medical or psychiatric care. If this relates to you or someone you know right now, seek immediate professional help—call or text 988 (Suicide & Crisis Lifeline, 24/7) or go to the nearest Hospital or Emergency Room.
